steps.title: Traditional Design: 8 Weeks
steps.narration: You know how to design systems. Requirements gathering, trade-off analysis, documentation, reviews, iteration. The problem? It's painfully slow. Eight weeks for a solid design is normal.

steps.title: Where Time Goes
steps.narration: Most time is spent on mechanical work: synthesizing requirements from scattered sources, researching prior art, drafting documentation. Your unique value‚Äîjudgment‚Äîgets only a fraction of the time.

steps.title: AI Accelerates the Mechanical
steps.narration: AI excels at exactly what slows you down: synthesizing scattered inputs, generating options, drafting documentation. Let AI do the heavy lifting on mechanical work.

steps.title: You Focus on Judgment
steps.narration: While AI handles the mechanical, you focus on what only you can do: applying context, making decisions, adding organizational knowledge. Your judgment is irreplaceable.

steps.title: Amplified: 5 Weeks Total
steps.narration: The result? Eight weeks compressed to five. Same quality, faster delivery. You're not cutting corners‚Äîyou're eliminating waste. That's the amplified architect!

steps.title: Phase 1: Requirements Synthesis
steps.narration: Feed AI your meeting notes, Slack threads, tickets, stakeholder emails. Ask it to synthesize requirements, identify ambiguities, and suggest clarifying questions. AI-heavy phase.

steps.title: Phase 2: Prior Art Research
steps.narration: Ask AI how others have solved similar problems. What patterns exist? What are the known pitfalls? AI can survey the landscape faster than you can read documentation.

steps.title: Phase 3: Design Generation
steps.narration: Have AI propose two or three architectures with trade-offs. You're not accepting AI's design‚Äîyou're using AI to rapidly explore the solution space.

steps.title: Phase 4: Trade-off Analysis
steps.narration: This is YOU-heavy. Apply your judgment to AI's options. What does AI not know about your org, team, and constraints? What would you regret in two years?

steps.title: Phase 5: Documentation
steps.narration: Let AI draft the design doc from your decisions. You refine and correct inaccuracies. AI generates diagrams from your descriptions. Draft fast, polish carefully.

steps.title: Phase 6: Review Preparation
steps.narration: Ask AI to anticipate reviewer questions. What are the weakest parts of this design? How would a skeptic critique it? Walk into reviews prepared for anything.

steps.title: Output Quality = Prompt Quality
steps.narration: AI output quality depends entirely on prompt quality. A vague prompt like 'design a payment system' gets you generic, unhelpful output. Garbage in, garbage out.

steps.title: Pattern 1: Context First
steps.narration: Always explain your situation before asking for solutions. Current scale, expected growth, tech stack, team expertise. Context transforms generic advice into specific guidance.

steps.title: Pattern 2: Constraints Explicit
steps.narration: Team size, timeline, budget, compliance requirements‚Äîall constrain solutions. Make them explicit. A solution perfect for a ten-person team fails with four engineers.

steps.title: Pattern 3: Specific Questions
steps.narration: Ask the exact questions you need answered. Not 'what should I do?' but 'should we use Stripe or build our own gateway, given these constraints?'

steps.title: Pattern 4: Request Options
steps.narration: Ask for two or three alternatives with trade-offs, not one 'best' answer. You make the decision‚ÄîAI shows you the landscape. That's the architect's advantage!

questions.question: What's the main reason AI accelerates design work?
options: AI makes better decisions than humans
AI handles mechanical work (synthesis, drafting) so you focus on judgment
AI eliminates the need for design reviews
AI writes better code than humans
questions.explanation: AI excels at mechanical tasks‚Äîsynthesizing inputs, generating options, drafting docs. You excel at judgment and context. Combining them eliminates waste without cutting quality.

questions.question: In the amplified timeline, what happens in Days 1-2?
options: Implementation begins immediately
AI synthesizes requirements from scattered inputs
Design reviews are conducted
The team takes planning meetings
questions.explanation: AI quickly synthesizes requirements from meeting notes, Slack threads, and tickets‚Äîwork that traditionally takes a week of human effort.

questions.question: What's the key insight about AI and judgment?
options: AI should make all the important decisions
AI is amazing at generating options; you're amazing at judgment‚Äîcombine them
Human judgment is no longer needed
AI replaces the need for senior engineers
questions.explanation: AI generates options and documentation rapidly. You apply irreplaceable judgment and organizational context. Together, you're faster than either alone.

questions.question: Which phase should be 'YOU-heavy' (your judgment dominant)?
options: Requirements synthesis
Prior art research
Trade-off analysis and decisions
Documentation generation
questions.explanation: Trade-off analysis requires YOUR judgment‚Äîwhat AI doesn't know about your org, team, constraints, and what you'd regret in 2 years. This is irreplaceable human insight.

questions.question: What should you ask AI during Review Preparation?
options: What's the best programming language?
What questions will reviewers ask? What are the weakest parts?
How much will this cost?
Who should attend the review meeting?
questions.explanation: AI can anticipate reviewer questions and identify weak points in your design. Walk into reviews prepared for tough questions and skeptical critique.

questions.question: In Phase 3 (Design Generation), what should you ask AI for?
options: The single best architecture
2-3 architecture options with trade-offs
Complete implementation code
A list of team members to assign
questions.explanation: Ask for multiple options with trade-offs. You're not accepting AI's design‚Äîyou're using AI to rapidly explore the solution space, then applying your judgment.

questions.question: Why does 'Design a payment system' produce poor AI output?
options: Payment systems are too complex for AI
The prompt lacks context, constraints, and specific questions
AI doesn't understand payments
You should never ask AI about payments
questions.explanation: Vague prompts get generic output. Effective prompts include context (your situation), constraints (team, budget, timeline), and specific questions to answer.

questions.question: What makes constraints 'explicit' in a prompt?
options: Listing them in bullet points
Stating team size, timeline, budget, tech stack, and compliance requirements
Using technical jargon
Making the prompt longer
questions.explanation: Explicit constraints tell AI about your real-world limitations. A solution perfect for a 10-person team fails with 4 engineers. Make constraints concrete.

questions.question: Why request 2-3 options instead of asking for 'the best' solution?
options: AI can't determine what's best
More options means more work for you
You make the decision‚ÄîAI shows you the landscape of possibilities
It's just a convention
questions.explanation: Requesting options with trade-offs lets YOU make the informed decision. AI explores the solution space; you apply judgment to choose. That's the architect's advantage!
